title.narrative: AfDB, 2020-2022 (new), Affirmative Finance Action for Women in Africa (AFAWA)
AfDB, 2020-2022 (new), Affirmative Finance Action for Women in Africa (AFAWA)

description.narrative:
Afrikanska utvecklingsbanken (AfDB) har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering motsvarande 75 MSEK för att genomföra "Affirmative Finance Action for Women in Africa (AFAWA) initiative" under 2020-2022. Programmet är femårigt och stödet kan komma att förlängas. Svenskt stöd föreslås i nuläget för 2020-2022. Insatsen syftar till att bidra till att öka tillgängligheten till finansiella tjänster för kvinnor i Afrika genom (i) mobilisera garantier för kvinnors företagande (ii) ge tekniskt stöd till privata finansiella institutioner och kvinnoledda/ägda företag och (iii) verka för konstruktiv och stödjande policyer, lagstiftning och regleringar i de respektive utvalda länderna. Stöd från strategin för Sveriges regionala utvecklingssamarbete med Afrika söder om Sahara kommer att gå till komponenterna för tekniskt stöd respektive policy och lagstiftning (enabling environment). Afrikanska utvecklingsbanken kommer att implementera insatsen tillsammans med flera partners, däribland African Guarantee Fund, privata finansiella institutioner, regeringar, AU, RECs och UN Women.
Insatsens budget för de två utvalda komponenterna uppskattas initialt till 750 MSEK (75 MUSD). Ambitionen från banken och givares stöd har därefter ökats. 79 945 MUSD har redan under 2019 mobiliserats. Detta omfattar skriftliga löften från Frankrike (25 MUSD), Nederländerna ( 27,945 MUSD) och Storbritannien (12 MUSD) och åtaganden från Italien (11 MUSD) och EU (4 MUSD). En gemensam fond för jämställdhet (Gender Equality Trust Fund) har etablerats inom Afrikanska Utvecklingsbankens avdelning för Gender, Women and Civil Society som en mekanism för att kanalisera dessa resurser,

The African Development Bank (AfDB) has applied to Sida for funding of 75 million SEK to carry out the "Affirmative Finance Action for Women in Africa (AFAWA) initiative" in Africa during the period 2020-2022. The total period of implementation of the program is 5 years with the possibility for extension though the Swedish support is for 2020-2022.
The intervention aims at closing the financing gap for women in Africa by (i) mobilize guarantees for de-risking lending to Women Empowered Businesses (WEBs) (ii) provide direct technical assistance to Private Finance Institutions (PFIs) and WEBs and (iii) Support a conducive policy, legal and regulatory environment in the respective targeted countries to foster the participation of WEBs. Among these pillars of the intervention, the planned support from Swedish Strategy for Regional Development Cooperation with Sub-Saharan Africa will go towards the technical assistance and enabling environment components. AfDB will implement the initiative with different partners including the African Guarantee Fund, private finance institutions, governments, the African Union (AU), Regional Economic Commissions (RECs), and UN Women.
The intervention’s budget for the TA and enabling environment is initially estimated to be roughly 750 Million SEK (75M USD). However, the ambition from AfDB and the commitment from donors has arisen with USD 79.945 million already mobilized from the donors in 2019. These include written commitments from the Governments of France (USD 25 million), the Netherlands (USD 27.945 million), and the United Kingdom (USD 12 million), and pledges from Italy (USD 11 million), and the European Union (USD 4 million). A Gender Equality Trust Fund is established to as a mechanism to channel these resources which is hosted within AfDB’s Gender, Women and Civil Society Department (AHGC).

The AFAWA program aims to bridge the finance gap for women entrepreneurs and drastically transform the financial landscape in Africa through the following outcomes. i. Women Empowered Businesses increasingly access credit facilities from Private Finance Institutions ii. Women Empowered Businesses increasingly use financial services offered by the Private Finance Institutions iii. Private Finance Institutions improve and diversify their product offering/services to Women Empowered Businesses and iv. The Policy, legal and regulatory environment is strengthened to foster the participation of Women Empowered Businesses

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

title.narrative: Multi-donor arrangement for the Gender Equality Trust Fund
Signed letter of participation and multi-donor arrangement

description.narrative: - The AFAWA initiative is still at a preparatory phase with the annual work plan shared last week and the oversight committee meeting held today (12/1/2020). Thus, it is impossible to discuss result at this point. However, it would be worth mentioning that the Bank has made significant progress in mobilizing resources and interest for the initiative.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
